profiledesc.creation: Text converted by SPI Content Sciences Inc., March 2003.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Dr. Patrick James Nicholson the author of In Time: An Anecdotal History of the First Fifty Years of the University of Houston came to the University of Houston as a lecturer in Management in 1951. In 1956 he became Executive Director of Development and Assistant to the President and he was named Vice President of University Development in 1957, a position he maintained until his retirement in August of 1981. This collection includes correspondence, brochures, reports and newspaper articles concerning many university-related topics as well as a small amount of personal material.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. Patrick James Nicholson (1921-1999) is best known as the author of In Time: An Anecdotal History of the First Fifty Years of the University of Houston. He received a BA from Rice University in 1942, an MBA from Harvard in 1946, and a Ph.D., from the University of Houston in 1959. Nicholson came to the University of Houston as a lecturer in Management in 1951. He continued until 1956, when he became Executive Director of Development and Assistant to the President. He was named Vice President of University Development in 1957, a position he maintained until his retirement in August of 1981. Honorary positions Nicholson held included Past President of the American College Public Relations Association; Past President of the Houston Council on World Affairs; Past President of the Institute of Ophthalmology, Texas Medical Center; and N.Y. Academy of Sciences. He was a member of Phi Kappa Phi; Phi Eta Sigma; Sigma Xi; and Omicron Delta Kappa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dr. Patrick J. Nicholson Papers consist of eleven records center cartons, one manuscript box and two oversized boxes. The collection includes correspondence, brochures, reports and newspaper articles concerning many university-related topics and a small amount of personal material. Some folders contain a variety of materials relating to that particular folder topic. Materials in the collection date from 1933 to 1979, with the majority dating from the mid-1960s to the mid-1970s.

The collection is divided into four series: Correspondence, University of Houston, Personal, and Oversize. The collection arrived in little discernible order and with little arrangement. An arrangement scheme has been imposed in consultation with the Archivist. For preservation reasons the collection has been re-boxed and re-foldered. New folder titles conform, as much as possible, to original folder titles. Exceptions were made when the folder title was obviously incomplete, incorrect, or confusing. Original item order has been preserved whenever possible.

Much of the collection concerns the University of Houston, or involves University of Houston groups, regardless whether the words "University of Houston" are part of the folder title. Topics relating to the University of Houston include the university in general, fundraising activities, history of the university, financial statements, and testimony before the Higher Education Commission, among many others. While the personal portion of the collection is relatively small, it has been maintained to provide background information and perspective to the researcher. It includes a variety of materials including Nicholson's dissertation. Additionally the collection contains an extensive range of newspaper articles relating to both UH and non-UH subjects.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dr. Patrick J. Nicholson Papers, Courtesy of Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Information of acquisition method not available.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: Terms are either Library of Congress Subject Headings or taken from local sources.

scopecontent.p: This series dates from 1958 through 1969, with one folder from 1976. It is the largest (fifteen boxes) and the strongest series within this collection. It consists of letters from Nicholson to a variety of people including donors, potential donors, and well-known associates of the university among others. The folders in this series cover a wide range of university related topics. Due to Nicholson's job responsibilities as Vice President of University Development, fundraising receives a strong emphasis within the correspondence series. Materials are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, Ph.D. Dissertation, First Draft January 1959
Correspondence, Excellence Campaign Dinner UH Foundation Honoring Workers, November 15, 1965

scopecontent.p: This series dates from the 1940s to 1979 and covers a wide range of materials and topics relating to the University of Houston. Types of materials include reports, studies, brochures, class notes, and articles. Topics range from building dedications and general history to testimony by university officials before various commissions. Also included in this series are page proofs for Nicholson's book In Time. Original folder titles have been maintained as much as possible. The materials in this series were in no discernable order and an order has been imposed in consultation with the Archivist. This series has been divided into five sub-series: General History, Financial Records, Development, Teaching, and Subject Files. In general the folders in each sub-series are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.p: This series consists mainly of brochures, invitations and Christmas cards, which do not relate to the University of Houston. They have been maintained with the collection to give the researcher a more complete perspective on Nicholson's life. The folder entitled "Hitler Wager" contains correspondence between Leopold L. Meyer, of Foley Brother's Dry Goods Company, and H.R. Cullen concerning a wager between the two men. Additional topics include organizations and clubs with which Nicholson was involved, including the Hibernians and Allegro. The Hibernians are an Irish Catholic organization dedicated to the protection of "American democracy, liberty of conscience and freedom of religion," and Allegro was an organization that sponsored a debutante ball each year. This series is arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Dissertation: An Experimental Investigation of the Effects of Training Upon Creativity, 1959
Social: Center Club of Hotel America, 1963
Houston Division of the Ancient Order of Hibernians in America, 1964-1968
Brochure: Modern Values In Politics: Women And The Labor Movement, 1975

scopecontent.p: This series contains extensive newspaper articles relating to both university and non-university issues. The university topics include Texas Governor Smith's 1970 visit, university sports, the university in general and early university history. The newspaper articles relating to non-university topics include additional materials on the Hibernians and Allegro.
